wikitext.*:
{{disambig-more|Sir Gawain and the Green Knight|[[Sir Gawain and the Green Knight (disambiguation)]]}}
{{book
|title=Sir Gawain and the Green Knight
| image = Sir Gawain and the Green Knight 1925.png
|editor=[[J.R.R. Tolkien]], [[E.V. Gordon]], [[Norman Davis]] (2nd edition) 
|publisher=Clarendon Press, Oxford
|date=[[23 April]] [[1925]]
|format=Hardcover; paperback
|pages=240
|isbn=
}}
'''''Sir Gawain and the Green Knight''''' is an edition of the Middle English long poem [[wikipedia:Sir Gawain and the Green Knight|Sir Gawain and the Green Knight]], co-edited by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] and [[E.V. Gordon]]. It was published in [[1925]] by the Clarendon Press, Oxford.

Tolkien edited the main text and compiled the glossary, while Gordon provided the greater part of the notes,<ref name=db>[[Wayne G. Hammond]], [[Douglas A. Anderson]] (1993), ''[[J.R.R. Tolkien: A Descriptive Bibliography]]'': B7</ref> it also includes an introduction and a linguistic appendix. In [[1967]] a second edition was published, edited by [[Norman Davis]], where the introduction, notes, and appendix are largely rewritten.

The Modern English translation by Tolkien was published in ''[[Sir Gawain and the Green Knight, Pearl, and Sir Orfeo]]'' in [[1975]], edited by [[Christopher Tolkien]].

==Contents==
* Preface
* Introduction

* The Text
* Notes
* Appendix

* Select Bibliography
* Abbreviations

* Glossary
* Index of Names

==From the publisher==
{{blockquote|The study of ''Sir Gawain'', the finest of all the English medieval romances, was signally advanced by the publication in 1925 of the edition by the late Professors Tolkien and Gordon. This remained the most widely used text of the poem; but after forty years the time came for revision. The new edition pursues the aim of the first – to present an accurate text pleasantly, with sufficient apparatus to enable a reader to understand the rich but difficult language, and so to reach for himself an informed appreciation of the poem. The Text, and the uniquely full glossary, were revised to take account of recent views. The Introduction, Notes, and Linguistic Appendix were largely rewritten; and the book was entirely reset.}}
